Column Comment.0: SEISMIC SET SUBTYPE: The seismic set type column is used to enforce arelationship between the SEIS SET supertype and its valid sub types. Values for thiscolumn must be the name of the table that is the valid sub type for this row of data.Validentries include SEIS_LINE, SEIS_SEGMENT, SEIS_SURVEY, SEIS_PLAN,SEIS_WELL, SEIS_PROC_SET, SEIS_INTERP_SET or SEIS_3D.
Column Comment.1: SEISMIC SET: A seismic set is a super type of various types of seismic collections.
Column Comment.2: ACTIVE INDICATOR: A Y/N flag indicating whether this row of data is currently eitheractive / valid (Y) or inactive / invalid (N).
Column Comment.3: CHECKSHOT SURVEY TYPE: The type of checkshot survey that was conducted toacquire this data, such as VSP, inline checkshot, walkaway checkshot etc.
Column Comment.4: CHECKSHOT VELOCITY: Value of the surface to datum velocity measurement.
Column Comment.5: CHECKSHOT VELOCITY OUOM: Checkshot velocity original unit of measure
Column Comment.6: DEPTH DATUM: The name of the depth datum used as reference for this data
Column Comment.7: DEPTH DATUM ELEVATION: the value of the measurement from the depth datumfor this data.
Column Comment.8: ORIGINAL UNIT OF MEASURE for this row of data
Column Comment.9: DIRECTIONAL SURVEY IDENTIFIER: Number uniquely identifying each directionalsurvey.
Column Comment.10: SOURCE: The individual, company, state, or government agency designated as thesource of information for this row.
Column Comment.11: DIRECTIONAL SURVEY UWI: The directional survey that is associated with this wellseismic. the directional survey will be conducted in one of the well bores involved,often the bore hole where the receivers are located, but in cross bore hole surveyeither hole may be involved.
Column Comment.12: EFFECTIVE DATE: The date that the data in this row first came into effect.
Column Comment.13: EXPIRY DATE: The date that the data in this row was no longer active or in effect.
Column Comment.14: ROW_MANAGEMENT_GUID: This value may be used to provide a global uniqueidentifier for this row of data. Use of this column is not mandatory, but if used,optional PPDM NOT NULL and UNIQUE INDEX constraints provided in the datamodel DDL should be created.
Column Comment.15: RECEIVER UNIQUE WELL IDENTIFIER: unique well ID for the well in which thegeophone receivers are located.
Column Comment.16: REMARK: Narrative remarks about this row of data.
Column Comment.17: SEISMIC PATH: Whether the path measured is one way or two way.
Column Comment.18: SOURCE: The individual, company, state, or government agency designated as thesource of information for this row.
Column Comment.19: UNIQUE WELL IDENTIFIER: A unique name, code or number designated as theprimary key for this row. This UWI is the well in which the source points are located.
Column Comment.20: CHECKSHOT SURVEY IDENTIFIER: Number uniquely identifying each seismicsurvey that was run.
Column Comment.21: SURVEY RUN NUMBER: The checkshot survey run number assigned by theoperator performing the service.
Column Comment.22: VERTICAL SEISMIC PROFILE TYPE: A reference table identifying valid types ofVSP. For example, upgoing, downgoing, ...
Column Comment.23: ROW CHANGED BY: Application login id of the user who last changed the row.
Column Comment.24: ROW CHANGED DATE: System date of the last time the row was changed.
Column Comment.25: ROW CREATED BY: System user who created this row of data.
Column Comment.26: ROW CREATED DATE: Date that the row was created on.
Column Comment.27: ROW_EFFECTIVE_DATE: A system assigned date that specified when a row of datais effective from a systems perspective. This may be the date that a row of data wasmade available to end users, for example.
Column Comment.28: ROW_EXPIRY_DATE: A system assigned date that specified when a row of data isno longer effective from a systems perspective. This may be the date that a row ofdata was no longer available to end users, for example.
Column Comment.29: PPDM ROW QUALITY: A set of values indicating the quality of data in this row,usually with reference to the method or procedures used to load the data, althoughother types of quality reference are permitted.
